TypeSignature.Value: .class nested public auto ansi beforefieldinit ListView/CheckedIndexCollection extends System.Object implements class System.Collections.ICollection, class System.Collections.IEnumerable, class System.Collections.IList
type ListView.CheckedIndexCollection = class interface IList interface ICollection interface IEnumerable

Docs.summary: Represents the collection containing the indexes to the checked items in a list view control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection> stores the indexes to the checked items in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control. Items can be checked only if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckBoxes%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control is set to `true`. The indexes stored in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection> are index positions within the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection>. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection> stores all items displayed in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control.
The following table is an example of how the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection> stores the items of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> as well as their checked states in an example <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control.
|Index|Item|Checked state in the ListView| |-----------|----------|-----------------------------------| |0|Item1|Unchecked| |1|Item2|Checked| |2|Item3|Unchecked| |3|Item4|Checked| |4|Item5|Checked|
Based on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection> example in the previous table, the following table demonstrates how the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection> would appear.
|Index|Index of checked item in ListViewItemCollection| |-----------|-----------------------------------------------------| |0|1| |1|3| |2|4|
You can use the properties and methods of this class to perform a variety of tasks with the collection. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection.Contains%2A> method enables you to determine whether an index position from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection> is one of the indexes stored in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection>. Once you know that the item is in the collection, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection.IndexOf%2A> method to determine the position of the index in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection>.

remarks.format: ## Remarks You cannot create an instance of this class without associating it with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control.

Docs.returns: if the specified index from the for the is an item in the collection; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection.Contains%2A> method enables you to determine whether an index position from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection> is one of the checked indexes stored in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection>. Once you know that an item is in the checked index collection, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection.IndexOf%2A> method to determine the position of the index in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection>.

public: property int Count { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the number of items in the collection.
Docs.value: The number of items in the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property enables you to determine the number of checked items in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>. You can then use this value when you are looping through the values of the collection and need to provide a number of iterations to perform the loop.

Docs.returns: The zero-based index in the collection where the specified index of the is located within the ; otherwise, -1 if the index is not located in the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Once you know that an item is in the checked index collection (using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection.Contains%2A> method), you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection.IndexOf%2A> method to determine the position of the index in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection>.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the collection is read-only.
Docs.value: if the collection is read-only; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is always `true` for this collection. The items in the collection can only be modified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This indexer enables you to get a specific index from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection>. The index stored in the collection is an index into the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection> of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> that represents a checked item in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView>.

remarks.format: ## Remarks You cannot change the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckedListBox.CheckedIndexCollection> class directly. To add an item to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckedListBox.CheckedIndexCollection>, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListViewItem.Checked%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Removes all items from the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks You cannot change the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection> class directly. To clear the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.CheckedIndexCollection>, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListViewItem.Checked%2A> property to `false` for each <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListViewItem> in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewItemCollection>.
